Is this PR Dead ?

No, it's just a work in progress on my github: https://github.com/jbonofre/beam/pull/3

For visibility, I think it's better to keep the PR on Apache Beam and use step by step commits.

I will merge my "local" PR as soon as the review is complete.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11390130/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11390130)

Coverage remained the same at 70.489% when pulling **0066ca8d9bca3a5e2106548f2736351913c7f681 on tweise:apex-3.6.0** into **3bffe0e0014bdd6ae73dc2e8ecfc2b61d066120c on apache:master**.

R: @dhalperi 
CC: @aviemzur

R: -@dhalperi @kennknowles 

I believe this can be done by simply changing the command-line arguments to `rsync`. Kenn knows more.

Adding `--delete` to the `rsync` command is the right way to do this bit. I think there's a further need for a couple of things like a `provided` scope dependency from examples to archetypes. I've hit issues even then so I think we may have a build order issue just within this module.
I am generally anti README throughout the codebase. This should be well-documented on the Javadoc for `HadoopFileSystem`, and probably also on the Beam website.
The `README.md` files we have right now are typically left over from when these files were their own projects and not integrated with the old Dataflow 1.x SDKs.
Fair enough. And fully agree for the Beam website.

R: @kennknowles @dhalperi 

Should be API compatible for all users who do not implement Coder directly, which should be a very small amount.

It is worth considering also making the constructor for `Coder` package-private and directing users to implement `(Structured/Atomic/Custom)Coder`

This is the minimal backwards-incompatible change for https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2829 that will require a worker dance.
Thanks for the feedback. I'm updating the PR by adding `--delete` instead of `rm -r`.
This LGTM
Had to also update the CoderFactories to be able to resolve the parent Coder type.
Still LGTM
@iemejia I thought you might be interested in this.
Run Flink ValidatesRunner

Updated worker version for new worker that is compatible.

If `tempLocation` is not specified:
  `INFO: No tempLocation specified, attempting to use default bucket: dataflow-staging-us-central1-996210899482`

If both `tempLocation` and `stagingLocation` is not specified
`INFO: No tempLocation specified, attempting to use default bucket: dataflow-staging-us-central1-996210899482`
`INFO: No stagingLocation provided, falling back to gcpTempLocation`
Done

I've split this into a few smaller commits, of which 	815e576 may be useful to re-review, given the recent activity on coder methods.

@kennknowles
run dataflow validatesrunner
@aaltay PTAL as this is already done in Java now.

R: @tgroh I have done a few different sorts of searches for `PipelineRunner` in the worker and I don't think it is an issue. There is some chance that it appears in the signature for some method being called, though that would be quite strange and probably erroneous code.

I played around with this a bit by rebasing on top of master, and found it is a nice improvement but doesn't quite work yet.

I created the followng files:

```
gcs-recursive/file1.txt   # contains "cat"
gcs-recursive/somedir/file2.txt  # contains "dog"
```

Then I ran: `gsutil cp -r ~/gcs-recursive gs://BUCKET/`

Using `gsutil`: `gsutil ls 'gs://BUCKET/gcs-recursive/**/*.txt'`

```
gs://BUCKET/gcs-recursive/file1.txt
gs://BUCKET/gcs-recursive/somedir/file2.txt
```

However, with the same glob, TextIO only reads `file2.txt`
LGTM, I'll merge.

I just saw that Coder was made into an abstract class, which could obviate the need for an intermediate ContextSensitiveCoder class (and make it possible to adapt existing coders gradually over time, possibly post-stable-release if the APIs are appropriately marked). Let me know what you think.

isn't.

On Fri, May 5, 2017 at 12:10 PM, Eugene Kirpichov <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Actually there's a bug in WriteBundlesToFiles, flagged by findbugs:
>
> } else {
>   // This means that we already had too many writers open in this bundle. "spill" this record
>   // into the output. It will be grouped and written to a file in a subsequent stage.
>   c.output(unwrittedRecordsTag,
>       KV.of(ShardedKey.of(c.element().getKey(),
>           ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(SPILLED_RECORD_SHARDING_FACTOR)),
>           c.element().getValue()));
>   // <----- Should have "return;" here, otherwise we fall through below and get an NPE
> }
>
> I ran BigQueryIOTest with coverage, and this code path is not hit, as well
> as none of WriteGroupedRecordsToFiles.
>
> Please add a unit test exercising this code path, and then the PR is good
> to go.
>
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2883#issuecomment-299551101>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AUGE1VMZCdmVB2v97ug-bH72IYWzl7xMks5r23QlgaJpZM4NQHC6>
> .
>
Ah -- it looks like it wasn't using the patched version of the SDK. Looks good now.

Can you make this change without moving stuff to a new file? Then it'll be clearer to see what's going on, and if the perf is OK we'll investigate why moving stuff around (and nothing else) is changing things.
